list_definition.definition: to (be able to) receive (sounds) by ear

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Speak louder – I can’t hear you
I didn’t hear you come in.

list_definition.definition: to listen to for some purpose

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Part of a manager’s job is to hear workers’ complaints.

list_definition.definition: to receive information, news etc, not only by ear

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: ‘Have you heard from your sister?’ ‘Yes, I got a letter from her today’
I’ve never heard of him – who is he? This is the first I’ve heard of the plan.

list_ex_of_english: Visual responses further show the user that what she said was heard and is being acted on.
Parents of young hearing children often augment their verbal labelling of objects with gestures.
First, results were more clear-cut for the group hearing 'happy' background music.
In the overt condition, participants were asked to overtly repeat each of the nonwords they heard during the exposure phase immediately after they heard it.
Hearing a sentence twice cannot be better than hearing it once unless the second exposure produces additional processing.
Thus, children heard each novel word a total of 12 times per normal game session (twice in each of six models).
Surely this shows that you heard the chimes even before you noticed it?
One group were trained in the impending condition, hearing both verbs prior to the events.
